text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, but that would be another possibility, I think, uh- Patient: Um hum. Doctor: -that we could consider. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Uh, if you’re, uh, again, the easiest thing is going to be to do the hormone therapy straight up. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: So, uh, we could potentially do the hormone therapy and then do the vaccine, also. Okay? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, uh. Patient: What did you think about that? Because I know you think differently than I do. Doctor: And so the Xtandi trials we have are Xtandi plus, uh, one of the drugs affect kind of the hormone pathways in different ways. Uh, so there’s some reason why they would work together with Xtandi. Uh, one of them is an immune drug itself. Uh, that immune drug, that, that trial, you get either the Xtandi plus the immune drug or just the Xtandi alone, but it requires biopsy. Uh, the other, the other trial we have is Xtandi plus, uh, a drug that affects we think a signal that the cancers can use as an alternative to the hormone signal. So they kind of switch over. So our idea is to block both signals to see if that would help. That, I think you get both drugs, uh, but, again, it also requires a biopsy. Family Member: Right.

text: Patient: You know, I'm not retiring tomorrow. Doctor: No, we don't want to leave you hanging. Patient: I mean, I don't think I am. Doctor: Right. So you're not planning it? Patient: Yes. Right. Doctor: -and then decide if you know you're even eligible, or that you're even interested after you review it one more time. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And then if it's good, then they sign you and then we go, and if you're like eh I don’t know, and then we think of something else. No pressure. Okay. Patient: Okay. Doctor: All right. text: Family Member: You look cute. Doctor: Thank you. You know it’s interesting how guys never notice and every one of the spouses has noticed. (Laughs) Patient: Well it’s something, a non-prescription over-the-counter thing doc. Doctor: Oh, okay. Patient: They didn’t have antivert. Family Member: They don’t seem to use it. Doctor: Oh you were in Canada. Family Member: The doctor didn’t even want to – he wouldn’t prescribe it, then he did prescribe it and we went to the pharmacy and they said we don’t carry it. Patient: But he directed us to an over-the-counter thing that worked really well. So that helped a lot. Doctor: It must have been scopolamine or something. Family Member: Yeah it was for anti-nausea. Patient: Anyway so I understand I have one point four from point four? Doctor: Yes. So the PSA is going up and the scans are showing slight worsening.

text: Family Member: Aside from hormones. Healthcare Professional: So they stay on the hormones. Family Member: Oh. Healthcare Professional: So he stays on the hormones but then we add to it. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Either a second-line hormone like he was talking about that they’re looking at this trial using it earlier. Family Member: Okay. Healthcare Professional: Or - Doctor: There are six drugs that have been approved by the FDA right now specifically for hormone-resistant prostate cancer. Family Member: Oh. Doctor: Two of those six are chemos. One is immunotherapy, one is a bone-targeted therapy for bone metastases and two are pills. So there are six drugs in addition to the conventional, old-fashioned hormone therapy that we only use if the cancer becomes hormone-resistant. Healthcare Professional: And there are other ones in development right now.

text: Patient: Do they have people that know how to put in an IV? Doctor: Yes they do. Well yeah. Family Member: So you think it would be one IV and then all the drugs through the IV? Doctor: Right. Yeah. Family Member: That’s much better. Doctor: That way you don’t get poked five times. If you have five blood draws. Family Member: So how are you feeling about how he is doing? Patient: Disappointed. Doctor: …this is a slight set back that Xtandi didn’t last us as long as I had hoped it would. And honestly I don’t know if that is part of the sort of resistance of BRC - BRCA mutant disease or not. Family Member: Yeah. Doctor: Nobody does really at this point because very few people have been really treated with Xtandi up front like that. Family Member: Yeah.

text: Family Member: For prostate? Doctor: So what we’re doing – yes, yeah, within prostate cancer. So what we’re doing now is what we’re proposing is that we screen your uh blood, it’s a blood test, that to look for any of those eight genes or mutations that if your cancer has those then I would recommend going on this particular study which gives you these medications which are pills that you would take and we’d monitor you to see if it’s likely to be helpful. Family Member: Is it a type of chemo? Doctor: It is not. It is something called parp… so more like what we call targeted therapy. Okay but it’s different from the immune therapy that you were having. Patient: Okay. Doctor: And I think it has a pretty good shot at working like I said if you had one of those mutations. Patient: Okay as far as working what do you mean by that? I mean is it something… Doctor: Working against – shrinking the cancer and helping – working against the… Family Member: Targeting drugs and genes (doc and fam talking at the same time.) Doctor: Targeting exactly the cancer that you have. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Now there is another option, I know you’re completely reluctant to go on chemotherapy. You know there is obviously that would be the standard treatment that you know we would – if we advise that and if you decide you want that you could easily get it in lots and closer to home.

Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
Doctor-Patient-Conversation-Analysis-pos.displayed_text: Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.
